Jennifer Aniston regresa a la televisión con la serie "The Morning Show"
02 Nov 2019, 10:24 by Reuters
LONDRES, 1 nov (Reuters) - Jennifer Aniston regresará este viernes a la televisión en "The Morning Show", una serie original para el nuevo servicio de suscripción de videos de Apple Inc, en la que la actriz se reúne con su hermana de la comedia "Friends", Reese Witherspoon.
En la serie de 10 episodios, Aniston interpreta a una conocida periodista de televisión en un programa matutino ficticio del que su anfitrión masculino, interpretado por Steve Carell, ha sido despedido en medio de acusaciones de acoso sexual.
La actriz de 50 años, que alcanzó la fama global con "Friends", protagonizó una serie de películas después de que terminara el exitoso programa que se emitió de 1994 a 2004, entre ellas "Horrible Bosses", "The Break-Up" y "Marley & Me", además de algunas actuaciones especiales en la televisión.
"No se trataba realmente de televisión versus película", dijo Aniston a periodistas en una proyección de "The Morning Show" en Londres, refiriéndose a la posibilidad de asumir un papel protagónico en la pantalla chica.
"Fue realmente el programa (...) Me encantan los 'talk shows' matinales y aprender sobre el mundo que hay detrás es simplemente fascinante (...) Fue lo más gratificante que he hecho en años", agregó.
"The Morning Show" aborda los temas destacados del movimiento #MeToo, que ha llamado la atención sobre el acoso y abuso sexual de mujeres en los campos del entretenimiento, los negocios y la política, así como el envejecimiento.
"No he sentido necesariamente que el envejecimiento me haya afectado porque siento que (ahora) estoy trabajando más que nunca antes", dijo Aniston.
"El #MeToo de todo, estamos tratando de encontrar nuestro camino y entender esta nueva normalidad. Y creo que el programa hace un muy buen trabajo al arrojar luz sobre eso", agregó.
Witherspoon, quien ganó un Oscar y encarnó a la hermana de Aniston en "Friends", interpreta a una periodista joven. Ambas actrices también fueron productoras ejecutivas de "The Morning Show".
"Ahora es diferente. Tenemos mucha más experiencia. Tenemos mucha más sabiduría. Hemos aprendido mucho", dijo Witherspoon a periodistas sobre cómo era volver a trabajar con Aniston. "Y sentimos que nos hemos dado cuenta de qué historias queremos contar", agregó.
Apple TV+ se lanzará el viernes.

(Reporte de Sarah Mills. Escrito por Marie-Louise Gumuchian. Editado en español por Lucila Sigal)
text:
Jennifer Aniston returns to television with the series "The Morning Show"
02 Nov 2019, 10:24 by Reuters
LONDON, Nov 1 (Reuters) - Jennifer Aniston will return to television on Friday at "The Morning Show," an original series for the new Apple Inc video subscription service, in which the actress meets with her sister from the comedy "Friends", Reese Witherspoon.
In the 10 episode series, Aniston plays a well-known television journalist in a fictional morning show from which his male host, played by Steve Carell, has been fired amid sexual harassment allegations.
The 50-year-old actress, who achieved global fame with "Friends," starred in a series of films after the successful show that aired from 1994 to 2004 ended, including "Horrible Bosses," "The Break-Up," and "Marley & Me", in addition to some special performances on television.
"It was not really about television versus film," Aniston told reporters at a screening of "The Morning Show" in London, referring to the possibility of taking a leading role on the small screen.
"It was really the program ... I love the morning talk shows and learning about the world behind it is simply fascinating ... It was the most rewarding thing I've done in years."
"The Morning Show" addresses the highlights of the #MeToo movement, which has drawn attention to the sexual harassment and abuse of women in the fields of entertainment, business and politics, as well as aging.
"I have not necessarily felt that aging has affected me because I feel that (now) I am working more than ever before," said Aniston.
"The #MeToo of everything, we are trying to find our way and understand this new normal. And I think the program does a very good job of shedding light on that."
Witherspoon, who won an Oscar and played Aniston's sister in "Friends," plays a young journalist. Both actresses were also executive producers of "The Morning Show".
"Now it is different. We have much more experience. We have much more wisdom. We have learned a lot," Witherspoon told reporters about what it was like to return to work with Aniston. "And we feel that we have realized what stories we want to tell," he added.
Apple TV + will launch on Friday.

(Report by Sarah Mills. Written by Marie-Louise Gumuchian. Edited in Spanish by Lucila Sigal)
